name: Rahima Foundation
mission: Today, the world celebrates vast technological advancements, yet every 9th person suffers from food scarcity (1). The rate of food insecurity in the United States is even higher, standing at 11.8% (2). In the Silicon Valley, specifically, that rate more than doubles to 24.8%—making every 4th person food insecure (3). A total of 720,000 people out of 2.9 million Bay Area residents live with food insecurity (3).
theoryOfChange: Rahima Foundation states it provides a safety net to low-income community members through monthly groceries, rent and utility assistance, hot meals, and educational support to address basic needs and food insecurity.
zakatClaimEvidence: Found 'donate zakat' on https://www.rahima.org/zakat-rahima (https://www.rahima.org/zakat-rahima); Website mission/programs mention zakat (Source: https://www.rahima.org/donate)

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Context dependent profile. Consider cause fit, risk profile, and evidence maturity before deciding.

components.evidence: Accepts zakat (+2); Muslim-focused organization (+2); Asnaf: fuqara (+5); Strong humanitarian service (+4)
components.name: Muslim Donor Fit

components.improvement_suggestion: Expand services to underserved populations or geographies with limited nonprofit coverage.
components.name: Underserved Space

alignment.rationale: Alignment 31/50: HIGH Muslim donor fit, domestic poverty cause area

components.improvement_suggestion: Publish a time-bound plan to deploy excess unrestricted reserves into mission delivery, while keeping a clear operating reserve floor.

all_citations.claim: Rahima International Foundation holds a 96.0/100 score and holds 65.0 months of working capital.
The organization reported total revenue of $4,006,022 and a program expense ratio of 95.3%.
The organization provides donation options that are Zakat-eligible.
The foundation offers volunteer opportunities for its soup kitchen and general operations.

areas_for_improvement: High cost per beneficiary relative to other domestic relief organizations
Limited third-party impact data to verify long-term educational outcomes

dimension_explanations.alignment: The foundation shows high alignment for Muslim donors as a Zakat-eligible entity addressing the urgent cause of domestic poverty [3]. Community engagement is further supported through active volunteer opportunities for local soup kitchens and distribution programs [4].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization demonstrates strong financial health with a Charity Navigator score of 96.0/100 and holds 65.0 months of working capital [1]. While its direct service model effectively distributes food and meat, the calculated cost per beneficiary is $14,222.072, which impacts its overall efficiency rating [2].

baseline_narrative.headline: Rahima International Foundation provides essential humanitarian relief through high-efficiency food distribution and educational support programs.
strengths: Exceptional program expense ratio of 95.3%, ensuring the vast majority of funds reach those in need
High fundraising efficiency with a cost of $0.00 per $1 raised
Strong liquidity position with 65.0 months of working capital
baseline_narrative.summary: Based in California, Rahima International Foundation focuses on alleviating hunger and financial insecurity while supporting students in their educational journeys [1][2]. The organization is recognized as Zakat-eligible, offering donors a direct way to fulfill religious obligations through domestic poverty relief efforts [3].

all_citations.quote: Rahima International Foundation strives to feed the hungry, assist the financially insecure

all_citations.claim: food distribution, soup kitchens, and meat collection
all_citations.quote: Programs: Food Distribution, Soup Kitchen, Meat Collection
Areas Served: San Francisco, CA, Santa Clara County, CA
Expand services to underserved populations or geographies

rich_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The foundation earns a high financial health rating due to its 95.3% program expense ratio, though its overall impact score is moderated by a high cost per beneficiary.

areas_for_improvement.context: The current <cite id="13">board consists of only 2 members</cite>, which falls below the recommended minimum for robust institutional oversight.
With <cite id="10">over 65.0 months of working capital</cite>, the foundation holds reserves far exceeding the industry standard, suggesting room for expanded program scaling.

bbb_assessment.summary: The organization maintains audited financials and high transparency scores but lacks a full BBB Wise Giving Alliance review.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The foundation has maintained a Gold transparency seal, indicating a willingness to share data despite governance limitations.
risk_factors: <cite id="13">Board size of only 2 members</cite> poses a risk to institutional sustainability.
<cite id="10">Excessive working capital (65 months)</cite> may indicate under-utilization of available donor funds.
case_against.summary: The primary concerns involve <cite id="13">limited board governance</cite> and an <cite id="10">excessive accumulation of assets</cite> relative to annual spending.

confidence.data_freshness: Data current as of 2023 Form 990 and 2024 Charity Navigator ratings
data_gaps: Small board size limits governance score
confidence.notes: Financial data is highly consistent across sources.

alignment.explanation: Strong fit for Muslim donors as a <cite id="6">zakat-eligible organization</cite> serving the <cite id="16">fuqara (poor) and masakin (needy)</cite> in the US.
alignment.improvement: The charity could <cite id="17">expand services to underserved geographies</cite> beyond Northern California to increase its alignment with broader humanitarian needs.

credibility.explanation: Donors can trust this charity due to its <cite id="5">96.0/100 from Charity Navigator score</cite> and <cite id="14">Gold Seal of Transparency</cite>. However, the <cite id="13">2-member board</cite> represents a governance risk.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the foundation should <cite id="13">expand its board of directors</cite> to at least five independent members to ensure diverse oversight.

impact.explanation: Operations are highly efficient with a <cite id="3">95.3% program expense ratio</cite>, though the <cite id="15">cost per beneficiary is high at $14,222</cite>.
impact.improvement: The foundation should <cite id="10">publish a time-bound plan to deploy excess unrestricted reserves</cite> into mission delivery to increase beneficiary reach.

donor_fit_matrix.evidence_rigor: Grade B - Verified outcomes and documented theory of change

grantmaking_profile.grant_strategy: Direct service delivery rather than grantmaking

rich_narrative.headline: Rahima International Foundation provides essential humanitarian relief through high-efficiency food distribution and educational support programs.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who prioritize high-efficiency domestic poverty relief and want to fulfill zakat obligations through a long-standing, asset-rich institution.
donor_motivations: Want to ensure 95.3% of their donation reaches programs
Prefer supporting Muslim-led domestic relief in California
Value organizations with significant financial reserves and stability
Seek to fulfill Zakat through verified local channels
giving_considerations: The organization has a very high cost per beneficiary
Governance is concentrated in a very small board
The foundation holds enough reserves to operate for 5 years without new funding
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking to fund rapid-growth startups or those who prefer organizations with large, diverse governing boards.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade B reflects verified outcomes and a documented theory of change, though missing external RCT-level evaluations.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: The foundation creates impact by providing direct nutritional and financial support to stabilize families, enabling students to pursue education.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that high-cost interventions like educational support translate into long-term self-sufficiency.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: While the foundation has high reserves, its -5.2% revenue CAGR suggests a need for renewed donor engagement to sustain long-term growth.

strengths.detail: The organization directs <cite id="3">95.3% of its expenses to programs</cite> and spends <cite id="9">$0.00 to raise every $1</cite> in contributions.
Rahima holds a <cite id="5">96/100 rating from Charity Navigator</cite> and has earned a Gold Seal of Transparency from Candid.
The foundation maintains <cite id="10">65.0 months of working capital</cite>, providing significant long-term operational security.

strengths_deep_dive: Rahima International Foundation demonstrates a unique financial model where <cite id="2">contributions of $3,988,637</cite> drive direct service delivery without traditional overhead burdens. Their <cite id="11">95.3% independent board</cite> oversees a mission that has remained consistent since <cite id="8">its founding in 1993</cite>. The organization's ability to maintain <cite id="12">$14.1 million in net assets</cite> while delivering direct services like <cite id="4">zakat distribution and food aid</cite> highlights a mature institution with deep community roots in Northern California.
rich_narrative.summary: founded in 1993, Rahima International Foundation is a California-based humanitarian organization dedicated to <cite id="1">alleviating hunger and financial insecurity</cite> within local communities. The foundation operates with a high degree of financial efficiency, reporting <cite id="2">$4,006,022 in total revenue</cite> for the 2023 tax year, with a <cite id="3">95.3% program expense ratio</cite> that ensures donor contributions are directed entirely toward service delivery. Their core operations include <cite id="4">food distribution, soup kitchens, and meat collection</cite>, alongside a robust educational support program for students. The organization maintains a <cite id="5">96/100 overall score from Charity Navigator</cite>, reflecting strong accountability and transparency. As a <cite id="6">zakat-eligible charity</cite>, Rahima provides a verified pathway for Muslim donors to fulfill religious obligations through <cite id="7">domestic poverty relief</cite> in areas including San Jose, Fremont, and Oakland. Despite its long operational history of <cite id="8">over 30 years</cite>, the foundation maintains a lean administrative structure, reporting <cite id="9">$0.00 in fundraising costs</cite> per dollar raised, which is exceptional within the international humanitarian peer group.
